metadata.titleEn: Asian monsoon experiment on the Tibetan Plateau (GAME/Tibet) dataset for global energy water cycle (1997-1998)
metadata.description:
The GAME/Tibet project conducted a short-term pre-intensive observing period (PIOP) at the Amdo station in the summer of 1997. From May to September 1998, five consecutive IOPs were scheduled, with approximately one month per IOP. More than 80 scientific workers from China, Japan and South Korea went to the Tibetan Plateau in batches and carried out arduous and fruitful work.
The observation tests and plans were successfully completed. After the completion of the IOP in September, 1998, five automatic weather stations (AWS), one Portable Atmospheric Mosonet (PAM), one boundary layer tower and integrated radiation observatory (Amdo) and nine soil temperature and moisture observation stations have been continuously observed to date and have obtained extremely valuable information for 8 years and 6 months consecutively (starting from June 1997).
The experimental area is located in Nagqu, in northern Tibet, and has an area of 150 km × 200 km (Fig. 1), and observation points are also established in D66, Tuotuohe and the Tanggula Mountain Pass (D105) along the Qinghai-Tibet Highway. The following observation stations (sites) are set up on different underlying surfaces including plateau meadows, plateau lakes, and desert steppe. (1) Two multidisciplinary (atmosphere and soil) observation stations, Amdo and NaquFx, have multicomponent radiation observation systems, gradient observation towers, turbulent flux direct measurement systems, soil temperature and moisture gradient observations, radiosonde, ground soil moisture observation networks and multiangle spectrometer observations used as ground truth values for satellite data, etc. (2) There are six automatic weather stations (D66, Tuotuohe, D105, D110, Nagqu and MS3608), each of which has observations of wind, temperature, humidity, pressure, radiation, surface temperature, soil temperature and moisture, precipitation, etc. (3) PAM stations (Portable Automated Meso - net) located approximately 80 km north and south of Nagqu (MS3478 and MS3637) have major projects similar to the two integrated observation stations (Amdo and NaquFx) above and to the wind, temperature and humidity turbulence observations. (4) There are nine soil temperature and moisture observation sites (D66, Tuotuohe, D110, WADD, NODA, Amdo, MS3478, MS3478 and MS3637), each of which has soil temperature measurements of 6 layers and soil moisture measurement of 9 layers. (5) A 3D Doppler Radar Station is located in the south of Nagqu, and there are seven encrypted precipitation gauges in the adjacent (within approximately 100 km) area. The radiation observation system mainly studies the plateau cloud and precipitation system and serves as a ground true value station for the TRMM satellite.
The GAME-Tibet project seeks to gain insight into the land-atmosphere interaction on the Tibetan Plateau and its impact on the Asian monsoon system through enhanced observational experiments and long-term monitoring at different spatial scales.
After the end of 2000, the GAME/Tibet project joined the “Coordinated Enhanced Observing Period (CEOP)” jointly organized by two international plans, GEWEX (Global Energy and Water Cycle Experiment) and CL IVAR (Climate Change and Forecast). The Asia-Australia Monsoon Project (CAMP) on the Tibetan Plateau of the Global Coordinated Enhanced Observation Program (CEOP) has been started.
The data set contains POP data for 1997 and IOP data for 1998.

Concept Completion.Question: What are the main data collection methods used in observing the Tibetan Plateau's interaction with the Asian monsoon system?
Concept Completion.Answer: automatic weather stations, portable automated mesonet, gradient observation towers, turbulence flux measurement systems, soil temperature and moisture measurement systems, radiosonde observations, precipitation gauge networks

Concept Completion.Question: Where were the observational data collected for studying the water cycle and atmospheric interactions on the Tibetan Plateau?
What challenges might researchers face when collecting data on the Tibetan Plateau over a long-term period?
Who are the primary contributors involved in the data collection efforts on the Tibetan Plateau for the GAME/Tibet project?
Concept Completion.Answer: Scientists from China, Japan, and South Korea

Feature Specification.Question: What are the key features and attributes of the atmospheric and soil observational stations used in data collection for understanding the energy and water cycle in high-altitude regions?
Feature Specification.Answer: multidisciplinary comprehensive observation systems, radiation observation systems, gradient observation towers, direct measurement systems for turbulent flux, soil temperature and moisture gradient observations, radiosonde measurements, networks for ground truth soil moisture observations, multi-angle spectrometers, automatic weather stations, portable automated meso-net stations, wind measurements, temperature measurements, humidity measurements, pressure measurements, radiation measurements, surface temperature measurements, soil temperature measurements, soil moisture measurements, precipitation measurements

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of utilizing multiple automated weather stations and multidisciplinary observation stations for data collection in understanding the Tibetan Plateau's impact on the Asian monsoon system?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Utilizing multiple automated weather stations and multidisciplinary observation stations can result in a comprehensive understanding of the interactions between the Tibetan Plateau's surface and atmosphere, providing valuable insights into how these interactions influence the Asian monsoon system. This approach allows for detailed measurements of various meteorological parameters, which help in assessing the hydrological cycle, atmospheric conditions, and energy exchanges over the plateau. Such data can improve climate models and forecasts, particularly in relation to monsoon patterns and their broader climatic impacts.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives of implementing a multi-disciplinary observation network with various automated weather stations and soil moisture measurement systems in the context of the Asian monsoon and Tibetan Plateau studies?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal of implementing a multi-disciplinary observation network with various automated weather stations and soil moisture measurement systems is to deeply understand the land-atmosphere interactions on the Tibetan Plateau and their impact on the Asian monsoon system. This network facilitates comprehensive data collection across different spatial scales, providing valuable insights into atmospheric conditions, soil moisture dynamics, and hydrological cycles in the region, thereby contributing to global energy and water cycle studies.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedures and instrumentation involved in setting up and operating a comprehensive atmospheric and soil observation station in a high-altitude environment like the Tibetan Plateau?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: In the Tibetan Plateau, comprehensive atmospheric and soil observation stations are equipped with multi-component radiation observation systems, gradient observation towers, and turbulence flux direct measurement systems. Soil temperature and moisture gradient observations are conducted, along with radiosonde operations and ground truth data collection for satellite remote sensing. Stations include automatic weather stations (AWS) that measure wind, temperature, humidity, pressure, radiation, surface temperature, soil temperature, and moisture, as well as precipitation. Portable Automated Meso-nets (PAM) provide additional turbulence observations.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements or methodologies have enabled the collection of comprehensive atmospheric and soil data in challenging geographic regions like the Tibetan Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: The establishment of multiple automated weather stations (AWS), comprehensive observation stations (like PAM), and the use of sophisticated instruments such as radiosondes, multi-component radiation observation systems, turbulence flux direct measurement systems, and soil moisture and temperature gradient observation networks have enabled the collection of extensive atmospheric and soil data in the Tibetan Plateau. Additionally, the integration of these technologies with satellite remote sensing for ground truth data collection has further facilitated comprehensive data collection in the region.
